title: Cleaning: What would happen if you wash a load of laundry without detergent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Considering that I wash my clothes with a plant-based detergent that has a hint of lavender in it, and I also add a full cup of white vinegar to the wash, if I were to run a load of laundry with only water - whether cold or warm - the results would be very disappointing and here’s why. First, the water supply in this area is loaded with minerals. This makes the water in this community “hard” and it leaves a white deposit on anything the water here evaporates from. This is why glasses that are half-filled with water end up with white rings inside the glass. Eventually these rings, if they aren’t scrubbed off, will become very resistant to cleaning. It’s for this reason that I add vinegar to the wash. The chemistry of white vinegar allows it to dissolve hard water deposits. Without it, my clothes come out of the dryer feeling stiff. Now let’s make matters worse and not use detergent either. The superficial dirt and dust will probably come off in a water-only wash, especially if I use warm water, but oil-soluble stains from butter, cooking oil, a salad dressing spills will still be there. The detergent emulsifies these fats and rinses them away. Without detergent, there’s nothing in the washing machine to remove stains. And then there’s the smell. If you’re accustomed to having your freshly laundered clothing smell like lavender, get ready for a surprise — your clothes will smell… damp. They’ll be half-clean and if you don’t immediately wash them again using detergent, the stains may set and remain there for the life of your garments. At a cost of less than 25 cents per load, I strongly recommend using detergent.

People wash clothes without traditional detergent like drycleaners, but something has to act like a dirt-release agent - even borax mineral, or sodium bicarbonate, or some thing that turns the water alkaline. The presence of humans creates a whole slew of output rubbish. Sloughing skin cells, oils and greases, and salty deposits from perspiration. All this is natural and our common ‘lot’, however to not wash it off is to invite skin problems and reduced resistance to disease. It changes the texture of the clothing and increases wear and tear on it. There is also a morale-factor. Clean clothes along with the bright and not dingy look and a fragrant smell of freshness, are morale boosters that make going through a rough day a little more pleasing. Some of our output is water-soluble and some is oil-soluble. In more backward societies, people just get as much water to dilute whatever is on the clothes and beat the hell out of it on the rocks in a side of a stream, in an effort to loosen it from the fibers and remove the smells and stains. They stretch it out in the sun which acts to bleach it somewhat, and the UV light and heat take care of some of the rest.

Cleaning: What would happen if you wash a load of laundry without detergent? Well, assuming it is washable in the first place and you used the recommended temperature, it wouldn’t be damaged. Detergent doesn’t all rinse out. If you only did this once, the left-over detergent from previous washings would leave you laundry pretty clean. If you made a habit of not washing with detergent, the detergent from prevous washing would all eventually wash out. In that case, all the water soluble stuff, which is most dirt and quite a bit of the organics, would come out in a decent washer. What would not come out would be all the oil-based stuff, which include body oil, body fragrance (ahem), many or most stains.

Yes of course it makes a difference. This is a test to do on yourself but you can then apply it to your laundry. Next time you are in the bath/shower, wash one.side with soap and washcloth , and the other only with hot water and a cloth to scrub . Then pay dry or wipe I don't think this matters. But if you want more accuracy dry your legs or whatever part you feel like testing with a blow-dryer to simulate the dryer heat and feel the difference or get a friend/loved one to see if they notice. For verification:hot water bath will simulate washer water. The washcloth used to scrub simulates the agitation of the clothes. Blow-dried simulates the heat from drier, PLEASE BE CAREFUL NOT TO BURN YOURSELF , NOT FOR CHILDREN TO TRY EITHER. SOAP / NON- SOAPis washing detergent. I bet you there is a difference if not noticed immediately then you will after a few wears of clothes washed without detergent.

There is most likely enough residual detergent in your clothes from past launderings that they would get perfectly clean this time, especially if you used warm water to wash them. But if you did this repeatedly you would find that as Viola Yee points out, the dirt just isn't coming out.

Water-soluable dirt would be rinsed away, but when clothes need washing it is the oil-based soils that we'd like to get rid of.  Detergent is needed to loosen the oil from the cloth and then hang onto the oil while dissolved in the wash water.  The detergent will keep the oily soils from re-depositing on the clothes. Sweat, for instance, has an oily component as well as the salt and water. Without detergent, the smell of the sweat would still remain.   Skin oil would not be rinsed away;  body odor also requires detergent to detach it from the clothes.

I've done this by accident more than once. The clothes get cleaner than they were. Most of them get clean enough to wear. Grease stains go nowhere (half the time even detergent doesn't touch them) but water-soluble substances rinse away. Most things smell OK, but workout clothes still smell sweaty, and aprons still smell like raw onions. I found that I really missed the fresh scent of the detergent.

I've tried this a cost saving measure. First time absolutely no difference. After a while your clothes get increasing grotty, smell wasn't a problem, but I did air dry on a washing line. The big problems seemed to be collars and cuffs which really didn't look impressive. It isn't a good idea long term, but once won't do any harm. It isn't an experiment I intend to repeat.

On average, people use approximately 4 times the detergent necessary for cleaning their clothes. Washing without detergent every other time can prolong the life of your clothing while economizing on detergent. Rinse cycles are often inefficient. Obviously, undergarments do require more thorough cleaning, but lightly-soiled items should be washed with significantly less detergent.

That depends on how those items have been washed in the past.  Most people use way too much detergent, and most washing machines fail to rinse efficiently.   I bought a front loading washing machine in 1999 and followed the instructions (although I was skeptical) and did not add any soap to the load.  I was astounded at how sudsy the water was!

As you wash without detergent more often you clothing would look progressively , , , ,  unwashed. and probably unappealing  to even the casual view. Best guess is that you might get away with using half the recommended  quantity of detergent and still be OK with an acceptable outcome. dirt and body oils need more than just water, be it soft or hard water to be lifted of the fiber of the fabric and rinsed away.

Your clothes will get wet. But, not much more. Before laundry detergents were developed, people washed their clothes with bar soap. Before that, they used ashes, sand and aromatic leaves combined, to help dissolve surface dirt, and improve the smell. This was very labor intensive, and results were unpredictable. There’s a reason laundry detergent exists. You should probably use it.

Anything ‘water’ soluble will wash away. Anything on the clothes that need the chemical ‘help’ from laundry soap to wash away will still be there including some smells. Kinda like taking a shower with no soap or shampoo. Hair gets really oily after a while! Sometimes, both choices of no soap is only choice one has. Constantly is not good idea for laundry or shower.

Despite my strong suspicion that this is a bot account I’m going to answer this. Washing clothes without detergent will get them cleaner and it will spread out the remaining dirt in a more consistent way. The defined edges on that coffee stain will fade. The nasty aroma of sweat and other biological stains will permeate things in the load that didn’t have it before you washed them. The dirt will form a suspension in the water (You are using water, aren’t you?) and some of it will go down the drain when you wring out or spin your clothes. The particles that don’t come off or that remain in water deposited on the clothes will remain.

Dirt gets washed away like normal, but anything oily, such as skin oil, will remain on the clothes. If a load is accidentally done without detergent and dried it probably would not matter for that one time especially if washed in hot water that can dissolve oils. There is not a lot of oil buildup anyway.

Most of the dirt will still come out. Detergent only helps get some of the more stubborn dirt. But the main action is to remove odors. Eventually washing in just water the clothes will not smell as clean. Also the dryer can with the higher heat temperatures set the stain and orders in making it more difficult to eventually get out. So maybe one wash out of 4 can be without detergents or reduce the amount you use because probably 80% of the people use too much

You end up with dirty clothes. I think it is necessary to use some kind of cleaning detergent or liquid in order to clean your clothing properly, in order to get out any dirt received through the air, and also to clean off any of your skin cells that have attached themselves to the clothes as you wear them. It also helps remove any perspiration smells that have come off your body and attached themselves to the clothing. Clean clothes smell and look better if they have been washed in soapy water properly.

Generally the items won't be cleaned. Same thing applies when you wash your hands. The chemicals you use - in both instances - allow the water to clean.  Source: Science on the Shelves.  Source: https://chem.ku.edu/sites/chem.ku.edu/files/docs/CHEM190/soap.pdf

I have had occasion to observe that you can wash at least a small load exactly that way. Once I rinsed the machine just running it unloaded and was surprised to see how much lathering was going on in the machine, probably a buildup of washing powder and liquid over time.
Clean but not as you know it.

It is too early to be laughing? You clothes would not be properly washed. . The mere fact of having warm water and the washing movement might release some dirt, example if it were mud, but it takes soap to do a thorough clean job..Enjoy your day!

Yes, we can clean clothes without detergent, but we can not remove the smell from them. However, you can try cleaning your clothes by washing your clothes in hot water and after that, you have to put your clothes in sun area so the smell would be removed.
Actully your clothes could get stained if the water has a smal amount of rust,or minerals in it.

They won’t get clean. Plain dirt will mix with water and some will come out with the water. Wash enough times and they will get cleaner. But any body oil or atmospheric contaminates that are not water soluble will remain.
No detergent means, among other problems, that you have no surfactants in the wash-liquor and then your whites will turn grey.
First of all, I wouldn't call it washing. My opinion of “washing" is to get something clean. Without using any soap how can it become clean? I wash my hands with soap, as well as my laundry. RHONDAK
If you wash clothes without detergent they come out less clean, and less good smelling, than if you had washed them with.
Your clothes will be damp and dirty. They may also still have odors that should be removed. Don’t dry them, just wash them again with laundry detergent.
You get well rinsed clothes, but not clean clothes. And when you put them in the dryer, you'll be setting the dirt, stains, oils, and stink in for life.
Nothing, you wouldn’t be washing, you would be just wasting your time.
